ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

BUILDINGS IN EXCESS OF
900 SQUARE FEET
(Building plans)


    1. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Law and National Development if he will consider waiving the Chief Building Surveyor's requirement of a registered architect's building plan for an existing or new temporary building of more than 900 square feet; and if he will consider requesting the Chief Building Surveyor's Department to sell standardised building plans for a three-room house of more than 900 square feet to the people in the rural areas.

Column: 1352



    The Minister for Law and National Development (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, building by-laws provide that sketch building plans may be accepted for erection of temporary houses of a floor area not exceeding 750 square feet. Where this area is exceeded, this restriction has not been applied too rigidly. In many cases where the floor plan submitted for a dwelling is for accommodation of a single family unit, the Chief Building Surveyor allows the use of sketch building plans for the erection of buildings even in excess of 900 square feet, without requiring an architect's building plan, provided that the structure is a simple structure and that the span of the roof trusses does not exceed the usual permissible length of about 20 feet.

    With regard to the sale of standardised building plans for a three-room house of

Column: 1353

more than 900 square feet in area, the Chief Building Surveyor is presently looking into the matter, and it is hoped to make these plans available for sale to the public very soon.

POULTRY SHEDS IN EXCESS
OF 900 SQUARE FEET
(Waiving of building plan requirements)


    2. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Law and National Development if he is aware that a temporary poultry shed which covers an area of more than 900 square feet requires a building plan to be drawn up by a registered architect before consideration for its approval can be made by the Chief Building Surveyor's Department; and if he will take steps to have this requirement waived and to allow the Primary Production Department Veterinary Extension Centre to handle such applications.

    Mr E. W. Barker: Mr Speaker, Sir, poultry sheds are not always small structures. Some of them are more than 25 feet wide, 100 feet long, and 15 feet high. The covered area of the shed is not the criterion used in determining whether architect's plans are required. The main consideration is the span of the roof truss and its design. If, in the opinion of the Building Surveyor, the service of an architect is required to ensure structural safety, he will advise the applicant to engage an architect.

    The Director of Primary Production has drawn up standardised plans for poultry sheds. Poultry farmers who wish to dispense with the service of an architect for erection of poultry sheds in excess of 900 square feet in area, should make use of the standardised plans prepared by the Director of Primary Production which conform with all the requirements.

    The Ministry of National Development is presently considering transferring the control of erection of temporary farm structures from the Chief Building Surveyor's Department to the Primary

Column: 1354

Production Department. Details are being worked out between the two departments.

HAWKERS' CENTRE AT
JALAN TENTERAM
(Facilities for motorists)


    3. Dr Augustine H. H. Tan asked the Minister for Law and National Development if it is planned to provide car parking facilities along, and bridges across, the canal adjacent to the proposed Hawkers' Centre to be built near Block 8, Jalan Tenteram, as those facilities will help to bring in business from motorists going along Jalan Toa Payoh.

CATERPILLARS IN MADRAS
THORN TREES
(Remedial measures)


    5. Mr Ng Yeow Chong asked the Minister for Law and National Development if he will ascertain from the Housing and Development Board what remedial measures will be taken to relieve the residents of the nuisance caused by caterpillars which infest the Madras Thorn trees in the Guillemard Road Estate.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Law and National Development (National Development Division) (Mr Ho Cheng Choon) (for the Minister for Law and National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, Madras Thorn trees are liable to be infested with caterpillars when new leaves begin to grow. As soon as any tree is discovered to be so infested, action is taken to destroy the caterpillars with a solution of insecticide. Some Madras Thorn trees in Guillemard Road Estate were recently infested with caterpillars and they were treated with insecticide.

    Mr Ng Yeow Chong (Mountbatten)(In Mandarin): Sir, can the Parliamentary Secretary inform the House how many such trees are there and how many are infested with caterpillars?

    Mr Ho Cheng Choon(In Mandarin): Sir, there are 99 such trees and only 12 are infested with caterpillars.

    Mr Ng Yeow Chong(In Mandarin): Sir, can the Parliamentary Secretary inform the House whether these infested trees will be cut down and new ones planted in their place?

    Mr Ho Cheng Choon(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, when the estate is redeveloped, I think the problem of cutting down those trees will then be solved.

ST. MICHAEL'S MARKET
(Accommodation for unlicensed hawkers and staircase to upper storey)


    7. Dr Augustine H. H. Tan asked the Minister for Health (a) if he has plans to enlarge St. Michael's Market to accommodate the unlicensed hawkers who are presently hawking in the concourse outside the Market; and (b) if it is proposed to provide a staircase leading directly from the concourse to the upper storey of that Market, so as to bring better business to the stall-holders upstairs.

    The Minister for Health (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Speaker, Sir, there are no plans to enlarge St. Michael's

Column: 1357

Market. All unlicensed hawkers plying in the concourse in the vicinity of the market were resited and given a place within the market on 18th November, 1970. Subsequently, through lack of firm enforcement, more unlicensed hawkers have gathered there. There are 42 vacant stalls and pitches in the market. It is not possible, therefore, to resite within the market all the unlicensed hawkers outside.

    The Housing and Development Board has, however, prepared plans for the construction of a new hawkers' centre at Jalan Tenteram. Those hawkers who cannot be resited in the existing market will be moved into this new market.

    There are two existing staircases within St. Michael's Market which already afford access to the upper storey. It is, therefore, not proposed to provide a staircase leading directly to the upper storey of the market.

    Dr Augustine H. H. Tan (Whampoa): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask the Minister what will happen to the unlicensed hawkers in the meantime, before the completion of the proposed hawkers' centre?

    Mr Chua Sian Chin: Sir, it is proposed to license them, which means that they will have to pay licence fees. These fees are at the moment being paid by the hawkers or stallholders inside the market, and therefore the present unlicensed hawkers, when licensed, will not have an unfair advantage over those inside the market.

    Dr Augustine Tan: Sir, in view of the numerous complaints that I have received regarding the high rentals of the market stalls, will the Minister consider lowering them not only for the present stallholders but also for the unlicensed hawkers who will be given licences?

    Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, sir, as far as I am concerned. I have not heard of complaints of high rentals in the market. But I am hearing this for the first time in this Chamber from the Member for Whampoa. May I say

Column: 1358

that the rentals in Government markets are highly subsidised. They are very reasonable.

    As far as St. Michael's Market is concerned, I think the major complaint is the unfair competition which the unlicensed hawkers are giving to the stalls inside the market. I remember my visit to the market - you will be surprised, Sir, that I myself do visit markets - during the last "Keep Singapore Clean" campaign. The stallholders came out to see me and their main complaint was, "We, the stallholders inside the market, pay licence fees and it is unfair of you to allow these unlicensed hawkers in the concourse outside the market to get away without paying any fees at all. Therefore, there is this unfair competition." In fact, that was the major complaint they made to me, but they made no complaint about high rentals.

    Dr Augustine Tan: Mr Speaker, Sir, will the Minister consider allowing the market stallholders to pay their rentals on a monthly basis, as they did some time ago? They have to make quarterly payments right now, and this constitutes quite a burden on them.

    Mr Chua Sian Chin: Sir, when we introduced these quarterly payments for market stallholders at the beginning of last year, there were complaints and grumblings about it. But these complaints have stopped now. It is quite human for people to grumble when there is some change. But may I say that if there are any genuine cases of hardship, we do consider each case on its merits or demerits.

    Mr Cheong Yuen Chee (Toa Payoh): Sir, is the Minister aware that this market is within a Housing and Development Board estate? It is not the policy of the Hawkers Department of the Housing Board to license unauthorised hawkers outside or within the concourse of the market. If it is, this will create a problem for me.

    Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, the question is very relevant, The problem with this market is due to the

Column: 1359

division of jurisdiction. In fact, the market comes under the control of my Ministry, but the concourse outside is under the control of the Housing and Development Board. Anyway, since both of us are on the same side, the Ministry of Health and the Markets Department of the Housing Board will jointly decide on the policy. But if the Member has problems, perhaps he can convey them either to the Hawkers Department or the Housing and Development Board, as we do have liaison with them, and we will take joint action.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim (Kallang): Sir, when all the unauthorised hawkers in the concourse outside St. Michael's Market have been licensed and resited in the new market at Jalan Tenteram, will the Minister allow more unlicensed hawkers to come along?

    Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker. Sir, my common sense tells me no. I think I shall follow my common sense.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: Mr Speaker, Sir, if that is the Minister's common sense, why does he allow the present unlicensed hawkers to trade outside St. Michael's Market, as a result of which there is unfair competition between them and the licensed hawkers? Is that common sense?

    Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, I did explain in my answer that it is because of the lack of effective enforcement that the unlicensed hawkers have gathered in that area. May I say that common sense is wanting, but perhaps the hawker inspectors did have a heart and so they did not take effective action. That is why this problem has arisen.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: Will the Minister explain whether the Hawkers Department will continue to have a heart when dealing with all the unlicensed hawkers at that particular market?

    Mr Chua Sian Chin: Common sense again tells me that they will continue to have a heart!

INCOME TAX
(Exemption for persons earning $6,000 per annum or less)


    8. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Finance if he will consider introducing amending legislation to exempt a person, who earns $6,000 per annum or less from payment of income tax, in view of the increase in the cost of living during the last few years.

    The Minister of State for Finance (Mr Tang See Chim) (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, the burden of income tax in Singapore is low because of the generous personal reliefs and the graduated rates of tax. At present about 120,000 out of 650,000 working persons are liable to income tax.

    Under the Income Tax Ordinance a taxpayer is allowed personal relief of $2,000 plus an earned income relief of 1/5th of his earned income up to a maximum of $1,000. A relief of $1,000 is given in respect of his wife, $750 in respect of his first child, $500 each for the second and third child, and $300 each for the fourth and fifth child. In addition, the taxpayer is allowed deductions on his life insurance premiums and compulsory contributions to the Central Provident Fund equivalent to that of the income up to a maximum of $4,000.

    The existing reliefs and personal deductions considerably reduce the burden of income tax. A married taxpayer, earning $6,000 per annum for example, with two children, will have to pay income tax of only $9, and a single person earning $6,000 per annum will be liable to pay income tax of $144. A married couple earning $6,000 per annum, but without children, will have to pay income tax of $84.

    There is, therefore, no reason why taxpayers in this income group should not make a small contribution towards paying for the security, educational, social and medical services of Singapore which are enjoyed by their families and by them.

Column: 1361



    The International Monetary Fund Mission, which studied our tax structure during 1969, has stated that our personal reliefs and deductions are generous and could well be reduced.

REVISION OF INDUSTRIAL
POLICY
(Withdrawal of incentives to foreign investors)


    9. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for Finance if it is feasible now for the Government to revise the industrial policy by withdrawing the investment incentives to future foreign investors.

    Mr Tang See Chim (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, the answer is no. Members may be aware that only last year the Government introduced amendments to the Economic Expansion Incentives (Relief from Income Tax) Act, 1967, which curtailed considerably the incentives offered to industrial investors. The major changes provided in the amendment Bill were as follows:

    (1) A reduction in the period of tax relief for export enterprises from 15 years to eight years in the case of exports as well as pioneer enterprises, and from 15 years to five years in the case of non-pioneer enterprises. However, in exceptional circumstances, the 15-year period is still available for very large enterprises with a capital investment of (Singapore) $1 billion or more, or those with a capital investment of $150 million of which more than half is owned by permanent residents of the republic.

    (2) The five-year tax relief provided for pioneer industries is now confined only to large enterprises with fixed capital investments of not less than $1 million.

Column: 1362



    (3) Expansion incentives are restricted only to those enterprises which incur additional capital investment in fixed assets of more than $10 million.

    (4) Depreciation allowances which were allowed to be carried forward to the post-pioneer period at accelerated rates which, in effect, extended the pioneer period beyond five years to six years or seven years are now no longer allowed to be carried forward. Thus this restricts the pioneer period to a maximum of five years.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister for Finance has emphasised the need for selectivity also in his budget statement. The Government has been very selective in approving incentives. Since November 1970, when the new amendment Bill was brought into effect, only nine pioneer certificates have been approved.

    Dr Augustine H. H. Tan: Mr Speaker, Sir, will the Minister of State consider lowering the qualification of $10 million required for expansion purposes to, let us say, $5 million or less, as this will encourage expansion, especially the smaller local industries? This is the qualification for pioneer status.

    Mr Tang See Chim: Mr Speaker, Sir, in considering the amendments to the Economic Expansion Incentives (Relief from Income Tax) Act last year, very careful consideration was given to incentives, and we decided upon $10 million because we thought this was a good round sum. Of course, should circumstances change, we would definitely consider either lowering it or increasing it.

    Dr Augustine Tan: If the Minister will recall the relevant sitting when this amendment was discussed, the then Minister for Finance indicated that any figure would do, and so he picked $10 million. At that time I thought that he was open to suggestions for an amendment, but I lost my chance at that stage.

Column: 1363



    Mr Tang See Chim: Sir, I do not recall the Minister saying that. Perhaps in his lighter mood he could have made that statement. But I can assure the Member for Whampoa that $10 million was fixed after due consideration. But, of course, as I have just said, should circumstances change and if we can with advantage lower the sum, consideration will definitely be given to it.

    Sir, I note that no less than $218,000 has already been spent on the underground car park at St. Andrew's Cathedral grounds. I shall be grateful if the Minister for Law and National Development can enlighten this House on what progress has been made on this project. I refer to page 7 of the Memorandum on the Development Estimates in which it is stated:

    'Work on the car park costing about $1.90 million is expected to start in the 1971/72 financial year.'

Sir, a sum of more than $200,000 has been spent. Can the Minister enlighten this House on how, why and where this sum has been spent? Also, when will the underground car park be completed and how many cars will it be able to hold?

    The Minister for Law and National Development (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, originally a small car park was planned to be built in the grounds of St. Andrew's Cathedral. The proposal was, however, temporarily shelved in

Column: 1364

favour of a bigger scheme. The study of the need of a bigger parking scheme is, in fact, in progress and construction work will begin as soon as the scheme has been finalised and approved. We are a little concerned that the digging and piling in the compound of the cathedral might in any way affect the building.

    As the original scheme was not proceeded with, a sum of $218,000, being the difference between the provision of half a million dollars and the revoted sum, was in fact not spent on the underground car park, but was used for establishing other car parks in Singapore. In fact, only $3,500 has been spent on preliminary work relating to the underground car park scheme at St. Andrew's Cathedral grounds, such as the construction of a model of the proposed car park, test bores and the printing of plans. Beyond that, I am afraid nothing much has been done nor has much money been spent.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Sir, when will the car park be completed? Another question is, how many cars will this car park hold?

    Mr Barker: I cannot say with any assurance when the car park will be completed because the plan has not been completed. It will take at least a few years. Neither can I say exactly how many parking bays will be provided. This depends on the completed plans. I have spoken earlier of a small-scale car park and then a second plan was for a bigger-scale car park. But at the most we can provide space for about 500 to 600 cars without affecting the Cathedral building itself.

    Sir, can the Minister please explain why the construction of a garbage composting plant is being contemplated? I note that this project is still subject to the Development Planning Committee's sanction.

    Mr Barker: Sir, the garbage composting plant is used to ferment garbage and produce compost from the garbage. Compost is an organic soil conditioner like sludge, manure and prawn dust. But it is a better grade of soil conditioner than sludge or manure.

    In 1962, it was proposed to establish a garbage composting plant by private enterprise with the participation of the Economic Development Board. It was then considered to be an economic proposition,

Column: 1366

as it was thought that the compost produced could be sold at profitable prices to neighbouring countries, in particular Malaysia. However, this proposal was not implemented because of the separation in 1965, following which the Malaysian market for compost was no longer open to us.

    Sir, times have changed again and, with the accelerated programme of planting trees, shrubs and other greenery in Singapore, the local demand for soil conditioners has increased substantially. It was therefore decided to reconsider the establishment of this plant in view of the changed circumstances.

    Sir, a comparative cost study has been undertaken by a committee of Government officials representing the various departments and Ministries. The committee has advised that it is comparatively cheaper to establish a garbage compost plant to dispose of garbage and refuse than to use the present conventional method of dumping garbage in the swamp at Tampines.

questions when he answered another Member's questions.

    Sir, a lot of money has been spent by Government on the reclamation of land. I wish to know how much has been spent on reclamation schemes to date, and what is the acreage of the reclaimed land. I am asking these questions because I have had occasion to travel along Bedok Road where I saw vast stretches of reclaimed land. However, I noticed that there are only several blocks of buildings there. In this connection, I wonder whether the Ministry of Law and National Development, in particular the National Development Division, has any plans to develop the reclaimed land and, if so, what they are. Also will some of the sites be offered to the private sector, like the "Golden Mile", for private development? I shall be grateful if the Minister can enlighten this House on my queries.

    Mr Barker: Mr Speaker, Sir, the areas reclaimed by the Government on the east coast are, of course, mainly meant for purposes which would be of economic advantage to the state. The reclamation, as the Member for Punggol knows, is being undertaken in four phases, and the reclaimed land will be utilised for the development, firstly, of a major highway to link the heavily congested eastern part of the republic with the city centre. Apart from this, the reclaimed land will also be utilised for development of open spaces and parks to provide the much-needed recreational amenities in our republic, tourist projects such as the Aquarama, bathing beaches, hotels, institutional buildings, including schools, junior colleges, recuperation centres and even homes for the aged, commercial centres and residential homes.

    The first two phases of the scheme which have been completed have yielded about 1,135 acres of reclaimed land. The proposal is to plan for some development on the sites around the middle of next year subject to development of the infrastructure for roads,

Column: 1368

sewerage, water and electricity. Although the preliminary plans for the development have been completed, the Government is now looking into the possibility of engaging a well-known consultant to review the plans for this major development.

    The Member for Punggol can rest assured that it is our intention to offer some of the sites to the private sector on similar lines to those offered under the three sales of urban renewal sites. The reserve price will have to take into account the cost of reclamation, including the provision of the infrastructure.

    May I say that the development of the military camp at Bedok was made during 1967 when expediency dictated the urgent need to provide a camp for use by our military personnel.
